title: Set up prerequisites
content:
This topic lists the tasks you must complete before deploying Operations Orchestration (OO) Containerized. 

Review each task and complete the ones that apply to your scenario.

Integration admin user in Service Management

Task Role Where to perform Environment
Create OO integration admin user in the Service Management IdM (on-premises) Suite administrator Service Management IdM  On-premises
Create OO integration admin user in the Service Management IdM (EKS) Suite administrator Service Management IdM  Amazon AWS
Create OO integration admin user in the Service Management IdM (AKS) Suite administrator Service Management IdM  Azure AKS
Create OO integration admin user in the Service Management IdM (OpenShift) Suite administrator Service Management IdM  Red Hat OpenShift

Databases

Create databases and respective users for OO Central, OO Scheduler, OO Controller, OO Session Manager, and AutoPass License Server.
You can skip this step if you plan to deploy on-premises and use the option to create database automatically in AppHub. 

Task Role Where to perform
Configure database on-premises Database administrator External PostgreSQL
Configure Amazon RDS for OO (EKS) Database administrator External PostgreSQL
Configure database on AKS Database administrator External PostgreSQL
Configure database on OpenShift Database administrator External PostgreSQL

Setup NFS/Elastic File System

  • Amazon AWS: Configure Amazon Elastic File System for OO.
  • Azure AKS: Configure Azure Premium Files for OO Containerized.
  • Red Hat OpenShift: Complete the following steps:

    1. Copy and save the following script as configureOONFS.sh:

      #!/bin/bash
SYSTEM_USER_ID=$1
SYSTEM_GROUP_ID=$2
CDF_HOME="/path/to/omt/installation/folder"
for x in oo_config_vol oo_data_vol oo_logs_vol oo_ras_logs_vol oo_data_export_vol; do pth="/var/vols/itom/oo/$x" && echo "${pth} *(rw,sync,anonuid=$SYSTEM_USER_ID,anongid=$SYSTEM_GROUP_ID,root_squash)" >> /etc/exports &&  mkdir -p $pth && chmod -R 755 $pth && chown $SYSTEM_USER_ID:$SYSTEM_GROUP_ID $pth && $CDF_HOME/scripts/setupNFS.sh $pth true $SYSTEM_USER_ID $SYSTEM_GROUP_ID; done

      Where CDF_HOME is the installation folder for OMT.

    2. Run the following commands to configure the volumes for OO: 
      chmod 755 configureOONFS.sh
sudo ./configureOONFS.sh <SYSTEM_USER_ID> <SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>
  • On-premises: Complete the following steps:

    1. Copy and save the following script as configureOONFS.sh:

      #!/bin/bash
SYSTEM_USER_ID=$1
SYSTEM_GROUP_ID=$2
CDF_HOME="/path/to/omt/installation/folder"
for x in oo_config_vol oo_data_vol oo_logs_vol oo_ras_logs_vol oo_data_export_vol; do pth="/var/vols/itom/oo/$x" && echo "${pth} *(rw,sync,anonuid=$SYSTEM_USER_ID,anongid=$SYSTEM_GROUP_ID,root_squash)" >> /etc/exports &&  mkdir -p $pth && chmod -R 755 $pth && chown $SYSTEM_USER_ID:$SYSTEM_GROUP_ID $pth && $CDF_HOME/scripts/setupNFS.sh $pth true $SYSTEM_USER_ID $SYSTEM_GROUP_ID; done

      Where CDF_HOME is the installation folder for OMT.

    2. Run the following commands to configure the volumes for OO: 
      chmod 755 configureOONFS.sh
sudo ./configureOONFS.sh <SYSTEM_USER_ID> <SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>

Create persistent volumes

Create persistent volumes (PV) using the template from the chart:

  1. Unzip the chart file and navigate to the oo/_utilities/values/persistent_storage/on_premises path.
  2. Open the volumes.yaml file using any text editor.
  3. For each persistent volume fill in the following:
    path:For example, for oo-config-vol, the path is /var/vols/itom/oo/oo_config_vol.
    server: For example, oohelm.myserver.net.
  4. Save the volumes.yaml file.
  5. Run the following command: 
    kubectl create -f volumes.yaml
  6. Check if the volumes were created successfully using the command: 
    kubectl get pv
